title: March Time Trials
description: Two full months of time trial data!
contents:
Contents Nitro Tracks Retro Tracks Bonus Tracks Day of Month Time of Day My first post on this blog looked at my Mario Kart time trial data for February 2022, the first month I began tracking this data. I’ve been practicing time trials on-and-off for a few years, so I didn’t expect any major time saves. In that post, most of the line graphs are flat because I was only improving my times by a handful of milliseconds. In contrast, when the new tracks were released I immediately saw major time saves as I learned the tracks. But I’ve been interested in seeing how the graphs look over a longer period of time. I’ve been playing more regularly than ever before, and recently I’ve been changing up my build to improve my speed. I’m expecting to see larger time saves than in February. This post reviews all my personal bests for MK8DX tracks in February and March, grouped by release group (nitro, retro, and bonus) and cup. I excluded the new tracks because this data is covered more extensively in the post linked above. Downward trajectories are more noticeable. I can also see when I stall out on improving my times for tracks. I’ll use these graphs as reference for which tracks I need to practice. The new tracks were released on March 17th and I played nonstop the following week. The spike on March 12th is when I switched my kart from the City Tripper to the Biddybuggy. Time of Day I wanted to see what time of day I set the most PBs and compare it to February. I began a new job in April and I tried to adjust my schedule to be less nocturnal during March. Trying out a new graph so apologies if this format is awkward. The left side is February and March is on the right. Changes in my sleep schedule are reflected in the graph. In March I mostly PB’d before midnight and I played in the middle of the day, a time in February I would typically be asleep. Is this a decent, roundabout way of tracking my sleep schedule? Idk. But it was fun to change up the data visualization from my normal bar/line graphs.

title: New Tracks!
description: My time trial and speedrun data for the new DLC tracks.
contents:
Contents Intro Time Trials 150cc 200cc Speedrun Intro Eight new Mario Kart tracks were released on March 18th, part of the first wave of DLC to come out over the next two years. The two new cups, Golden Dash and Lucky Cat, include amazing tracks such as Coconut Mall and Ninja Hideaway, and some less stellar tracks like Toad’s Circuit and Choco Mountain. Since the new tracks were released, I have grinding them in time trials and successfully completed two speedruns. Time Trials Time trials are the easiest way to learn and practice the new maps, especially before they were available in online play. I mostly practiced 150cc, but I’ve also begun practicing tracks in 200cc. 150cc The below graph shows every time trial PB I’ve set for the new tracks in 150cc. {"x":{"data":[{"x":[1647566760,1647576720,1647668400,1647866460,1648062840],"y":[127.516,126.901,126.889,125.823,125.007],"text":["dt: 2022-03-18 01:26:00

There were stark drops in my times as I learned and improved at the maps. Sharp drops typically indicate when I discovered a new shortcut that significantly saved time. Ninja Hideaway showed the most improvement, with approximately 15 seconds saved between my first and most recent PB. As the month went on, it became harder to improve my times and set new PBs. However, some tracks I practice far less than others because they’re not as fun (see: Tokyo Blur, Toad Circuit, and Sky Garden). Overall, my favorite tracks have been Ninja Hideaway, Coconut Mall, and Paris Promenade. I think the shortcuts on these tracks make them particularly fun. My favorite shortcut in all of the new tracks is in Coconut Mall, shown in the clip below. While most people know the shortcut through the shop, I’ve seen little mention of the extension of the shortcut. I wasn’t able to actually save time on it and because the path is so narrow I still often run into the railing trying to complete it. Still, it is very satisfying when I’m able to nail it correctly. 200cc Since online play randomly selects some courses to be played at 200cc, I’ve been trying to incorporate it into my practice more often. title: Biddybuggy or bust
contents:
Contents Overview The Run Future time saves Online Play Overview For years1 I have stuck with the same Mario Kart build: Isabelle, City Tripper, Leaf Tires, and Paper Glider. I know it’s a sub-optimal build, but I wanted to max out my abilities with that cart before switching to a meta build. Isabelle jazzed on the City Tripper. Yesterday I decided to make the switch. It was not the first day I tried the Biddybuggy–that was Valentine’s Day (where I set 16 PBs in one day). I tried speedrunning that night, but I was struggling with turns on the new build and had a lot of falls, so I cut the run short. I switched back to the City Tripper and didn’t think much of it. Then my speedrun times began to level out and I embarrassed myself in online play, so I was ready to give the Biddybuggy another shot. Folding to the meta.First I extensively practiced the time trials, and was setting PB after PB. I began getting a grasp of the biddybuggy handling. I knew if I tried the 48 track speedrun, I would set a fat personal best. Around 11 PM I tried to stream the run on Twitch, but my internet was having issues and I was getting a lot of dropped frames.2 For the first time I decided to just record the speedrun locally and upload it to YouTube. Once I started running, it quickly became obvious that my predictions were right. I had saved over half a minute before getting to the halfway point. The second half of the race had a handful of falls (future time saves) and I accidentally rigged the game to play the Animal Crossing winter track (notorious for horrible traction and adding excessive time). Still, I managed to easily PB by 48 seconds, an insane time save considering how many falls I had. {"x":{"data":[{"x":[1,2,3,4,5,6],"y":[7266,7222,7205,7190,7219,7142],"text":["attempt: 1

My reaction during the run was almost upset. Of course I was happy to PB, but I was frustrated for two reasons: 1. Why are two carts (Biddybuggy and Wiggler) sooo much better than other carts? 2. Why did I resist playing the meta for so long?3 Biddybuggy and Wiggler are basically the only two carts in the game.Time after time there were sections where I normally would’ve run into a wall or object, but the Biddybuggy allowed me to safely navigate around obstacles. During Dry Dry Desert I decided to risk going underneath a Poke to grab a coin, an unnecessary risk. After successfully grabbing it, I said aloud, “This cart is just giving me a confidence I didn’t know I was missing.” The Run After the run, I submitted my time to speedrun.com. At the time of writing this, I moved from 206th to 180th, an improvement of 26 spots. You can watch the full speedrun below. Disclaimer: I’d been awake for about 26-27 hours when I began the run. Be warned that since it was just me, I didn’t talk much and I mumbled a lot. While the recorded video contains gameplay audio, I was listening to my own music during the run. If I seem like I’m talking to myself, I was mouthing along song lyrics. When I did talk, I was often cursing out my gameplay or wondering why certain songs weren’t playing (problems with soundcloud). Future time saves There are a handful of major time saves still available: Neo Bowser City: one fall (SNES) Rainbow Road: one fall on shortcut on second lap Ice Ice Outpost: 3 falls - first lap landed too far right off first ramp, first and third lap final ramp cut in too late Ribbon Road: 2 falls - missed second ramp on first and second lap Animal Crossing: accidentally rigged for winter track And some more minor time saves: Donut Plains 3: botched shortcut Super Bell Subway: ran into subway on second lap Toad’s Turnpike: ran into bus on 3rd lap Music Park: botched final shortcut Cheeseland: twice went slightly off road near second chomp chomp, hit a wall Bone-Dry Dunes: ran into wall one turn Online Play Today I practiced online with the biddybuggy. The room I was placed in was pretty well balanced, with nearly everyone’s rating being between 7500-9000. The average rating going into the final game was 7882. I kept track of my results, and I’m content with how I placed. I landed in the top three 9 times (36%) and my lowest placement was 9th. My average result was 4.88. My rating at the end of the night was 7702. I use “years” loosely because I didn’t play much from late 2018 till the beginning of this year. Grad school got in the way of Mario Kart.↩︎ I’m currently on my neighbor’s internet and I’ll have my own installed on March 28th, so that should cut down on streaming problems.↩︎ Answer: I thought the City Tripper was cute and I liked committing to the bit of full Animal Crossing build.↩︎

title: February Time Trials
description: Reviewing my time trials PBs for February 2022.
contents:
Contents Nitro Tracks Retro Tracks Bonus Tracks All Tracks Day of Month Day of Week Time of Day In February 2022, I began keeping a spreadsheet of every time new personal best I set in Mario Kart time trials. Nitro Tracks The nitro tracks include the Mushroom, Flower, Star, and Special Cups. I set 28 PBs in nitro tracks in February. # A tibble: 15 × 2 track n 1 Mario Circuit 4 2 Thwomp Ruins 4 3 Twisted Mansion 4 4 Mario Kart Stadium 3 5 Dolphin Shoals 2 6 Rainbow Road 2 7 Bone Dry Dunes 1 8 Bowser's Castle 1 9 Cloudtop Cruise 1 10 Electrodrome 1 11 Mount Wario 1 12 Sunshine Airport 1 13 Sweet Sweet Canyon 1 14 Toad Harbor 1 15 Water Park 1 Mario Circuit, Thwomp Ruins, and Twisted Mansion tied for the most PBs set of the Nitro tracks.
